Abstract: This comprehensive review explores the emerging field of nanoparticles for oral delivery in food, focusing on their biological fate, evaluation models, and interactions with gut microbiota. The study examines various types of nanoparticles used in food nanotechnology and their potential applications in enhancing nutrient delivery and bioavailability. It critically analyzes existing evaluation models for assessing the safety and efficacy of these nanoparticles in the gastrointestinal tract. Furthermore, the review investigates the complex interplay between nanoparticles and gut microbiota, highlighting potential impacts on microbial composition and function. By synthesizing current research and identifying knowledge gaps, this review provides valuable insights for future developments in food nanotechnology and its implications for human health and nutrition.
